title: 115_s2161
content: The Act is titled the "Hadiya Pendleton and Nyasia Pryear-Yard Gun Trafficking and Crime Prevention Act of 2017". It addresses firearms trafficking. The "Hadiya Pendleton and Nyasia Pryear-Yard Gun Trafficking and Crime Prevention Act of 2017" amends Chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code by adding a section on trafficking in firearms. It prohibits the shipping, receiving, or transferring of two or more firearms in interstate or foreign commerce if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe it would violate federal, state, or local laws punishable by imprisonment exceeding one year. The Act prohibits the receipt of two or more firearms in interstate or foreign commerce if the person knows or reasonably believes it would violate laws punishable by imprisonment exceeding one year. Additionally, making false statements related to the purchase of firearms is also prohibited. The Act prohibits receiving multiple firearms across state lines if it violates laws punishable by over a year in prison. Making false statements regarding firearm purchases is also banned. Violators face fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both. Organizer enhancement allows for an additional 5-year sentence if the violation involves 5 or more individuals under the organizer's supervision. The term 'actual buyer' refers to the individual acquiring the firearm. The Act prohibits receiving multiple firearms across state lines if it violates laws punishable by over a year in prison. Making false statements regarding firearm purchases is also banned. Violators face fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both. Organizer enhancement allows for an additional 5-year sentence if the violation involves 5 or more individuals under the organizer's supervision. The term 'actual buyer' refers to the individual acquiring the firearm. A firearm being purchased, received, or acquired does not include any offense classified as a misdemeanor punishable by a term of imprisonment of 2 years or less. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and potentially amend sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of trafficking in firearms under section 932 of title 18, United States Code. This review includes assessing the penalty structure based on the number of firearms involved in the offense to align with Congressional intent. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and potentially amend sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of trafficking in firearms under section 932 of title 18, United States Code, to reflect the gravity of the offense. This includes increasing penalties substantially for violations committed by individuals associated with gangs, cartels, or organized crime rings.
